intro: Ceramanthus riparius, commonly known as the river ceramanthus, is a flowering plant native to the wetlands and riverbanks of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Ceramidaceae and is characterized by its slender, herbaceous stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, adapting well to aquatic environments. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, often floating or submerged depending on the water level. Ceramanthus riparius plays a role in stabilizing riverbanks and providing habitat for aquatic organisms.
